ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: History of Florence, Siena, and a bit on other cities between about 1200-1500; Italian writing and listening comprehension; some introduction to ideas behind urbanism as well as representation of cities in art and the developments in that field
Deeper understanding of Italian and the Urban landscape

The course covers a lot of medieval history and literature- we read excerpts from Dante, Petrarch, Boccaccio, etc., and the prof gave lectures on the history that were really helpful in understanding the context. we also covered a lot of art from this period, as well as city planning and design.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: interesting topics; fun, creative assignments; generally get to work with some funky texts from the Middle Ages and Renaissance; Simona is fantastic!

Things to improve: since this is a new class, I think the pacing is still a bit off. We spent too much time talking about ideal cities, when it would have been cool to talk about cities in other parts of Italy or in other time periods a bit more. There were also a few texts that felt a bit too long and were tough to parse through. However, I think these things will improve as course finds its footing.

strengths- interesting content, prof is very helpful and knowledgable, relatively easy to understand and helpful in improving italian speaking skills

weaknesses- workload was consistently pretty high and did not really follow the syllabus

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you have spent time in Florence, Rome, or Siena, absolutely! If you are interested in the history of urbanism in Italy, also would recommend. Otherwise, it may be a bit niche.
If you want to take an L5 this is certainly a good option, will of course be a lot of literature and reading of old Italian stuff but its good practice and leads to good discussion generally.
definitely an interesting italian course to take, and the prof is great
